PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1  The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is necessary in order to identify, 
formulate, and prepare the proposed Project. The PPTA will be used for preparing, mainly, a 
feasibility study, which will include preliminary designs; preliminary engineering; cost estimates; 
technical,  financial,  economic,  and  socioeconomic  analysis;  environmental  analysis;  social 
impact  assessment;  a  study  for  initial  benchmark  indicators;  and  a  project  administration 
manual. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  Four candidate road sections have been identified to be part of the feasibility study, an 
estimated 350km of roads total (see Table below).  Prioritization will be needed during the PPTA 
stage.  Under the PPTA, the proposed candidate road sections are at follow:

D.  Consulting Services 
5.  For the main portion of the PPTA, a firm of international consultants will be recruited 
using the quality-and cost-based selection procedure, with a simplified technical proposal and a 
80:20 proportion of quality to cost. The services will be implemented over about 7 calendar 
months and will require about 16 international person-months and 16 national person-months. 
Table A5.3 shows the summary of consulting services requirements; see Annex 6 for the outline 
terms of reference. For environmental assessment, one national individual will be recruited 
using the individual selection procedure to provide about 5 person-months of services. For 
social and resettlement assessment, one national individual will be recruited using the individual 
selection procedure to provide about 6 person-months of services (see Appendix 7 for the 
outline terms of reference).

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
8.    The Department of Roads (DOR) will be the executing agency for the PPTA. A project 
management unit is not envisioned. The government’s in-kind contribution will be provision of 
office  accommodation,  furnishings,  and  utilities.  The  government  will  provide  all  available 
reports, maps, and other pertinent data, and facilitate inter-agency coordination and applicable 
permits as necessary.  Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with the ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time) 
 
9.  The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A5.4.
